title: Vibha Masti
text:
personal mail
  
  
    
     college mail
  
  
    
     linkedin
  
  
    
     youtube
  
  
    
     medium
  

  
  
Hi there üëã! I am a Master of Computational Data Science (MCDS) student at the Language Technologies Institute of Carnegie Mellon University. I did my Bachelor‚Äôs degree in Computer Science and Engineering at PES University, Bangalore.
My primary focus is applied machine learning/research engineering. My research interests lie in natural language generation and understanding, music generation, code generation, and graph-based learning. You can find my publications here. In the past, I have interned at Apple, Goldman Sachs, Netradyne, and Vogo. You can find my resume here.
I believe in the power of visual storytelling and teaching. I enjoy making aesthetically-pleasing lecture notes that my peers at college (PES University) have been using to study. I was awarded by the Department of Computer Science and Engineering for my immense contributions through these notes. Feel free to check out my notes! They are categorized by subject (most of them are CS subjects, but some are math/science).
I learn to play the South-Indian instrument Saraswathi Veena in the Carnatic style. I also enjoy making YouTube videos about my experiences and interests. I have made videos about my college life, academic conferences, and more. You can check out my YouTube channel if it interests you!

title: Vibha Masti
text:
News

2023

[08/28] Officially started my Fall semester at Carnegie Mellon University!
[07/05] I wrote a Medium article on How I Scored a 334 on the GRE.
[01/09] I started my 6-month spring internship/co-op at Apple! I am so excited for this experience and unbelievably grateful.



2022

[12/04] I volunteered for the ISMIR 2022 conference in Bangalore, India from 4th to 9th December 2022.
[09/19] I attended the ECML-PKDD 2022 conference in Grenoble, France with my teammates to present at the MLG workshop. Check out my vlog on it!
[07/01] I traveled to Mumbai with my teammates to attend the IEEE TENSYMP conference and present our paper. I made a YouTube video about the experience!
[06/06] I started my summer internship at Goldman Sachs.
[06/03] Made my first ever vlog! It‚Äôs about my 6th semester of college which was (finally) in-person!

title: How I Scored a 334/340 on the GRE
text: Disclaimer: this post reflects my own experience and opinions and is not sponsored by any company.

2021

title: UE19CS201 - Digital Design and Computer Organization
text:
Course instructor: Prof.¬†Reetinder Sidhu


Syllabus and Class Notes



Unit
Syllabus
Vibha‚Äôs Notes




Unit 1
- Introduction
- Boolean Functions
- Truth tables
- Boolean Algebra
- Identities
- Logic minimization
- K- Maps
- Adder/Subtractor, Overflow
DDCO Unit 1.pdf


Unit 2
- Muxes, Decoders, Shifters
- Gate/Wire delays, Timing
- Latches, Flip-flops
- Synchronous logic design
- Finite State Machines
DDCO Unit 2.pdf


Unit 3
- FSM examples
- Counters, Memory array
- Carry-lookahead and Prefix adders
DDCO Unit 3.pdf


Unit 4
- Shift/add multiplier/divider
- Wallace tree multiplier
- Floating point
- Assembly Language, Machine Language
DDCO Unit 4.pdf


Unit 5
- Addressing Modes
- Performance analysis
- Single-cycle, Multi-cycle processor datapath and control
- Systolic array matrix multiply
- Overview of computer systems organization
DDCO Unit 5.pdf






Textbooks:

T1: ‚ÄúDigital Design and Computer Architecture‚Äù, David Money Harris, Sarah L Harris, 2nd Edition, Morgan Kaufmann, 2012




Reference Books:

R1: ‚ÄúDigital Design‚Äù, M Morris Mano, Michael D Ciletti, 6th Edition, Pearson, 2018
R2: ‚ÄúComputer Organization and Design‚Äù, David A Patterson, John L Hennessey, 5th Edition, Elsevier, 2016
R3: ‚ÄúComputer Organization and Design‚Äù, Carl Hamacher, Safwat Zaky, Zvonko Vranesic, 5th Edition, Tata McGraw-Hill, 2011

title: UE19CS205 - Automata Formal Languages and Logic
text:
Course instructor: Prof.¬†Preet Kanwal


Syllabus and Class Notes



Unit
Syllabus
Vibha‚Äôs Notes




Unit 1
- Mathematical Preliminaries
- Basic Notations
- Deterministic Finite Acceptors (DFA)
- Non-Deterministic Finite Acceptors (NFA)
- \(\lambda\)-NFA (Lambda-NFA)
- Equivalence of Deterministic and Non-deterministic
Finite Acceptors
- Reduction of the number of states in Finite Automata
(Minimization of DFA)
AFLL Unit 1.pdf


Unit 2
- Regular Expressions
- Connection between Regular Expressions Regular Languages
- Regular Grammars
- Properties of Regular Languages
- Pumping Lemma and identifying Non‚ÄìRegular Languages
AFLL Unit 2.pdf


Unit 3
- Context Free Grammars
- Parsing and Ambiguity
- Formal Definitions of Pushdown Automata
- Deterministic Pushdown Automata
- Non Deterministic Pushdown Automata
- Methods for Transforming Grammars
- Two important Normal Forms
- A Membership Algorithm for Context‚ÄìFree Languages
- Pushdown down Automata and Context Free Languages
AFLL Unit 3.pdf


Unit 4
- Properties of Context‚ÄìFree Languages
- Pumping Lemma for Context‚ÄìFree Languages
- The Standard Turing Machine
- Combining Turing Machine for Complicated Tasks
- Turing Thesis
- Recursive and Recursively Enumerable Languages
- Context Sensitive Grammar and Languages
- The Chomsky Hierarchy
- Some Problems that Cannot be solved by Turing Machine
- PCP
- Undecidable Problems for Recursively Enumerable Languages
AFLL Unit 4.pdf


Unit 5
- Propositional Logic: A very simple logic
- Syntax
- Semantics
- A simple knowledge Base
- A simple Inference procedure
- Inferences and Proofs
- Proof by resolution
- First Order Logic: Syntax and Semantics of First
order logic
- Numbers, Sets and Lists
- Example - The electronic circuit Domain
AFLL Unit 5.pdf






Textbooks:

T1: ‚ÄúAn Introduction to Formal Languages and Automata‚Äù, Peter Linz, Jones and Bartlett, New Delhi, India, 5th Edition, 2011
T2: ‚ÄúArtificial Intelligence ‚Äì A Modern Approach‚Äù, Stuart Russell and Peter Norvig, Pearson, 3rd Edition (Paperback), 2016




Reference Books:

R1: ‚ÄúTheory of Computation‚Äù, Michael Sipser, Cengage Learning, New Delhi, India, 2008
R2: ‚ÄúIntroduction to Automata Theory, Languages, and Computation‚Äù, John E Hopcroft, Rajeev Motwani, Jeffrey D Ullman, Pearson Education, New Delhi, India, 3rd Edition, 2009
R3: ‚ÄúTheory of Computation: A Problem‚ÄìSolving Approach‚Äù, Kavi Mahesh, Wiley India, New Delhi, 2012

title: UE19CS204 - Web Technologies
text:
Course instructor: Prof.¬†Vinay Joshi


Syllabus and Class Notes



Unit
Syllabus
Vibha‚Äôs Notes




Unit 1
- Introduction to WWW and Web protocols
- HTTP Request Response Formats
- URLs, Basic Markups & syntax
- HTML elements & attributes
- Web Form 2.0 and Form Controls
- CSS3.0-Styles and Style sheets
- Selectors, Style properties
- Box Model
- JavaScript Basics - (variables, scope and
lexical operator (fat arrow))
- JavaScript objects
Web Tech Unit 1.pdf


Unit 2
- RDOM Manipulations
- Events and Event Handling in JavaScript
- XML Vs JSON
- HTML5 (New Tags, New Inputs, Elements & API)
- JQuery Introduction
- Callbacks and Promises
- Single Page Application
- Asynchronous Communication
Web Tech Unit 2.pdf


Unit 3
- MERN Introduction
- React installation and application setup with web pack
- JSX
- React Classes and Components
- Rendering of elements
- Properties, State, Context
- Component lifecycle methods
- Refs & Keys
- Event Handling
- React Router
- Stateless components
- React Form & Controls
Web Tech Unit 3.pdf


Unit 4
- Understanding Node JS Architecture
- NPM Installation and Features
- Set up Node JS app
- HTTP Methods and Verbs
- Query String
- Callbacks, Buffers, Streams, File system
- MongoDB-Documents, Collections
- Reading and Writing to MongoDB, MongoDB NodeJS Driver
- Running a react application on NodeJS
Sorry, no notes üòï


Unit 5
- Introduction to Web services and REST APIs
- Express Installation and Server setup
- Building the application stack
- Routing, List API, Create API
- Error Handling
- Express Middleware, Express Scaffolding and Templates
Sorry, no notes üòï






Textbooks:

T1: ‚ÄúLearning PHP, MySQL & JavaScript‚Äù, Robin Nixon. May 2018, 5th edition, O‚ÄôReilly Media, Inc.
T2: ‚ÄúPro MERN Stack: Full Stack Web App Development with Mongo, Express, React, and Node‚Äù, by Vasan Subramanian. March 2017, Apress




Reference Books:

R1: ‚ÄúBeginning Node.js, Express & MongoDB Development‚Äù, Greg Lim, July 2019
R2: ‚ÄúLearning React, Functional Web Development with React and Redux‚Äù, Alex Banks and Eve Porcello, May 2017, O‚ÄôReilly Media, Inc.
